definitions.definition: a series of musical notes that are sung or played in a particular order to form a piece of music

examples.text: He was humming a familiar tune.
I can play a few tunes on the piano.
I don't know the title but I recognize the tune.
It was a **catchy tune** *(= easy to remember)*.
a football song sung to the tune of *(= using the tune of)* ‘When the saints go marching in’
The kids were picking out a popular tune on the old piano.
He wasn't allowed in the choir because he couldn't hold a tune (= sing the correct notes).

definitions.definition: to be/not be singing or playing the correct musical notes to sound pleasant

examples.text: None of them could sing in tune.
The piano is out of tune.

definitions.definition: to be/not be in agreement with somebody/something; to have/not have the same opinions, feelings, interests, etc. as somebody/something

examples.text: These proposals are perfectly in tune with our own thoughts on the subject.
The President is out of tune with public opinion.

definitions.definition: to be the person who controls a situation
to express a different opinion or behave in a different way when your situation changes

examples.text: Wait until it happens to him—he'll soon change his tune.

definitions.definition: to do whatever somebody tells you to
the person who provides the money for something can also control how it is spent
to behave in a different way from other people; to have different attitudes or ideas

examples.text: She was a gifted and original artist who marched to a different drummer.

definitions.definition: to change your opinion about somebody/something or your attitude towards somebody/something
used to emphasize how much money something has cost

examples.text: The hotel has been refurbished to the tune of a million dollars.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: unexplained alteration of tone. The verb is first recorded (late 15th cent.) in the sense ‘celebrate in music, sing’.
